job_title: CCR II in West Seattle, WA
pros: Ummm.... TBH, this place leaves much to be desired.
cons: Brow beating experience... If Horrendous energy was a call center floor, this would be the Taj Mahal. The immediate supervisors have recently been switched and I believe that is where the downward spiral began. If you are on assignment at the Pacific Tower Location for the call center as a CCR or CCR II be wary or make sure that the pay that you agree to is one that will be equal or the bad energy and condescending jargon from management bestows on the call center floor. To be honest, 7 staff members whom have been here for over 3, 4, and 5 years all sporadically quit over the coarse of a month. Hopefully with the new hires won't have the same experience. because it truthfully has the potential to be a great place to work. Good luck.

review_title: Former RN for 2 years and LOVED it!
job_title: Primary Care Nurse in Rainier Beach, WA
pros:
Excellent management, I felt like I was seen and heard whenever I had a need or constructive feedback. I also had the best coworkers! It was really great getting to work with an interdisciplinary team including providers, medical assistants, diabetes educators, behavioral health counsellors, social workers and eligibility specialists. Everyone there really cares about their work and the people that they serve, and each of them do what they can to meet each patient's need. 

I loved the level of independence and the fact that I was able to work at the top of my scope as a nurse. I also felt really supported by my coworkers.

Neighborcare Health truly puts their all into serving those of highest need and making sure healthcare is accessible to ALL. This is a huge reason why I loved getting to work with them! I would definitely recommend them if community health is what you're looking for!
cons:
Sometimes it felt like decisions would be made without incorporating every teams input prior to implementing a change that directly impacted their work, but there would be opportunities to provide feedback that would shape how these changes were implemented. I honestly think management was doing the best they could to resolve identified issues.

Another challenge with Neighborcare Health is that it is a non-profit facility that often runs into issues with providing resources to staff and patients due to lack of money allotted to various areas. For example, needing to hire more staff but genuinely not having enough funds to hire the people needed. You have to go into this position knowing there will be a large workload. I will say, this is common in many community health facilities. I was really passionate about the work that I did and the community I got to serve, so this challenges were things I was able to look past as part of the reality of working at a community health center.

pros: Good benefits, great DEI initiatives
cons: Low pay for the field, long hours

pros: Good mission, poor execution of it.
cons: Too many meetings. Nothing gets accomplished. They have meetings about planning meetings. Poor salaries.

pros:
Great mission, like everyone has stated
Has an influx of federal grant money due to Covid, and Neighborcare is catching up on its purchasing and resourcing
A lot of individuals are very dedicated to their work
the org is very socially conscious

A new CEO will be starting in June and this will bring turnover and change
The pay for many positions is low for the Seattle area

pros: Neighborcare is a wonderful place to work with people who are so passionate about community health. Management is also very supportive.
cons: The pay should be higher. It's not comparable to other community health organizations.

pros:
I just started with the organization, and I can say that I am quite impressed with the positive work environment and the wonderful support that I've received so far. The organization is very community focused and has a great mission. 
My new co-workers and bosses are extremely nice and very supportive.
cons: The parking situation can be challenging for employees as we are required to park on the street.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Seattle, WA
pros: Nice people, good direct management
cons: Pay is not competitive compared to similar jobs at king county

review_title: Wonderful team and connection with patients
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Seattle, WA
pros: Everybody cares about the work and patients. Nurses get to work to the top of our scope and constantly learn and grow clinical skills. Pay is decent for a community health center and leadership is really supportive of nurse autonomy and flexibility. It's great to work daytime and always have holidays and weekends off. Benefits are really good like PTO and healthcare (Kaiser), dental, vision. New interim CEO is doing a much better job communicating and listening to staff.
cons: Being a nonprofit the salary can't compete with hospitals. Hard to see how tough patients' lives are and how poorly the healthcare system is set up to help people (like being discharged from hospital without adequate home support, financial barriers to getting medications etc)

review_title: School-Based: Love the Kids, the Program Structure Needs Work
pros:
- Serving the kids/students is incredibly rewarding
- Fellow school-based staff are awesome folks, great teamwork and camaraderie with in-clinic staff
- Regular time off during school breaks (fantastic during winter holiday season and summers, but also means running out of PTO quickly)
cons:
- Low pay compared to comparable positions elsewhere (for all positions other than medical providers) and no consistent annual/cost-of-living pay raises 
- Benefits are just ok (health insurance options are either minimal coverage or quite expensive, PTO runs out quick when it has to be used over school breaks, retirement savings plan is fine but not great)
- Ongoing process inefficiencies and issues with communication between departments means repeatedly running into the same problems without finding a long-term fix
- School-based program is a relatively small part of Neighborcare, so generally feels like a low priority for executive leadership

job_title: Registered Dietitian,  Certified diabetes educator in Seattle, WA
pros: I have worked as an RD/DCES at Neighborcare Health for nearly 5 years. I feel very supported in my role by my supervisor, healthcare team, colleagues and management. I am fulfilled daily by helping our patients in an impactful way, and providing Nutrition and Diabetes care throughout the lifespan. I highly recommend working at this company if you are looking for a meaningful career and supportive work environment with flexibility. Excellent opportunities for Continuing Education offered.
cons: Working in healthcare throughout the pandemic has had its share of stresses.

review_title: Need leadership that reflects the community

review_title: Disappointing as an organization does not match the rhetoric
pros: Reach a diverse community...the front-line people are caring not because they work there but because they bring those attributes with them.
cons: Executive and management is not representative of the diverse communities they serve.

review_title: Do Not Work at Neighborcare if you really care
pros:
Diverse patient population
Use entire scope of practice
cons: Poor management, unsupportive HR, Clinic facilities need improvement, No IT support and unreliable EHR system, unhappy and overworked coworkers.  No vacation time (it is only PTO), if you are sick and do not have pto and call out even under the worst of circumstances, an employee will have to sign something and eventually be terminated, Frequent terminations, Low moral, and a complete lack of care, and respect for employees.

review_title: Good community health employer for advanced practice providers
pros:
Relationship between physicians and advanced practice providers (PA-C or ARNP) is very collegial.
Good supervision and friendly atmosphere to consult with other providers on cases.
Management is overall good.  Easy to communicate with.
PTO amount is average at first, but quickly can increase with years of service.
Decent CE policy.
Flexible scheduling and FTE for providers.
Health plan actually has a very reasonable deductible.
FTCA liability coverage is basically an occurrence policy.  Alleviates most concerns about tail coverage purchasing if you leave.
Compensation is probably above average for community health.
cons:
Occasional frustration with equipment.
Sometimes difficult patients.
Frequent interpreted visits which adds to time constraints.
High no-show rate.  Schedule visits often replaced with walk-in with unpredictable complexity.

review_title: Learn a lot, CEU’s, Good team
pros:
Team. Lots of potlucks. Supervisor bring in treats like trophy doughnuts. Each year we go out  to dinner to Cheesecake Factory. Learning  . They pay for CEU’s and they pay for us to take classes up to 40 hours and pay for renewing our CEU’s each year.
Goal is to bill out 100 encounters a day.
cons:
Hold more people accountable. Some people call in or don’t meet production and others have fill in.  The supervisor does hop in and code and bill with us. 
Working denials and phone calls.

pros:
Everyone (organization wide) seems to all work very diligently to achieve the mission "The mission of Neighborcare Health is to provide comprehensive health care to families and individuals who have difficulty accessing care; respond with sensitivity to the needs of our culturally diverse patients; and advocate and work with others to improve the overall health status of the communities we serve." I can see that everyone I work with are patient oriented and really want to help the patients as much as they can

-Interpreters are available at all times !!!! (This makes a very dramatic impact on patient access, we are improving overall public health with this step alone.)
-Nurses, MA's, Providers, all work very diligently for the patients
-Teamwork is a huge part of the work we do
cons:
-High turnover
-Very understaffed
-Low Morale
-No clear on boarding process (for any position)

review_title: Leadership Lagging and Massive Employee Turnover
